meanings.definition: To prolong or extend in time or space.
meanings.sent1: She kept protracting the meeting by asking unnecessary questions.
meanings.sent2: The construction project was protracting due to bad weather conditions.
meanings.sent3: The cat was protracting its nap by stretching and yawning repeatedly.
meanings.sent4: His apology seemed to be protracting, as if he couldn't get to the point.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's explanation was so protracting that the students started to lose interest.

meanings.sent1: The student was protracting his homework by taking frequent breaks.
meanings.sent2: The negotiations were protracting, causing frustration among the parties involved.
meanings.sent3: The comedian was protracting his joke, making the audience laugh even harder.
meanings.sent4: The suspense in the movie was protracting, keeping the viewers on the edge of their seats.
meanings.sent5: The customer was protracting the decision-making process, unable to choose between two options.
